isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 MODEL - HEATER AND AIR CONDITIONER BLOWER WITH THERMOSTAT TEMPERATURE CONTROL (SLEEPER) - TROUBLESHOOTING

item.para: Before beginning these test procedures, make sure the vehicle batteries are at 75% state of charge (SOC) or higher. This represents an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 13.4 volts. Batteries with an OCV of 12 volts or less are either completely discharged or have a dead cell.
Before beginning these test procedures, check any light or indicator lamp filaments that are suspected of being open (burned out). This is done to avoid unnecessary extensive circuit checks.

Before beginning these test procedures, inspect all connectors for loose or damaged pins, wires, etc. Refer to TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

When the technician determines that a fuse is blown, while checking its condition, he is directed to locate the cause of the overload condition and to repair it. While no further instruction on this procedure is listed in the diagnostic tables, the common procedure is as follows: isolate sections of the circuit, by disconnecting connectors, and measure the resistance to ground to find the circuit that is shorted to ground. Then locate the damaged spot in the wire or connector and repair.

Diagnostics for circuits that are malfunctioning by sticking in the on position are generally not covered in detail. It is assumed that the technician knows to check for a malfunctioning switch, relay, or solenoid.

entry.para: Does the blower run in either the low, medium, or high fan position?
Remove auxiliary bunk blower relay (441), move key switch to ignition position, and at circuit 13AT measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13AT, then repair.
At relay socket (441), measure voltage form circuit 13AT to 13-GAT.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 13-GAT, 75-GH, 75-GN, or 11-GBB to right cab ground stud (404), then repair.
At (B2) battery stud measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage at (B2) battery stud, then repair.
Remove fuse F10-B (location may vary) and check for open condition
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install F10-B and at circuit 14AU measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14AU, then repair.
At relay socket (441), measure voltage from circuit 75AX to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AX, then repair.
Bench test auxiliary bunk blower relay (441) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Replace defective auxiliary bunk blower relay.
Bench test auxiliary bunk blower relay (441) by applying +12V to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Replace defective auxiliary bunk blower relay.
Re-install (441) and disconnect switch (550). Move key switch to ignition position and at (550) circuit 75AR, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AS or 75AR, then repair.
Test bunk heater blower switch (550) by placing switch in low speed position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to L, and B to C.
(550), term. B to L, and B to C.
Test bunk heater blower switch (550) by placing switch in medium speed position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to M, and B to C.
(550), term. B to M, and B to C.
Test bunk heater blower switch (550) by placing switch in high speed position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to H, and B to C.
(550), term. B to H, and B to C.
Re-install blower switch (550). Move key switch to on position. Does blower motor run at low speed when blower switch is set to low position?
Disconnect conn. (51) and with the key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low speed position, measure voltage from circuit 75AC [coming from (80)] to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AC, conn. (80), or circuit 75AC, then repair.
Disconnect resistor and thermofuse assembly (41) and with key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low position, measure voltage from circuit 75AC to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AC, then repair.
At blower resistor and thermofuse assembly (41), measure distance from terminal 1 to 2.
At blower resistor and thermofuse assembly (41), measure resistance from terminal 2 to 3.
Reconnect blower resistor, and disconnect conn. (48). With key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low speed position, at (48) circuit 75AT [going to (N/L)] measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AT, then repair.
Remove sleeper high speed relay (481) and at circuit 75AT, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AT, then repair.
Bench test high speed relay (481) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Replace defective sleeper high speed relay (481).
Bench test high speed relay (481) by applying +12V to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Replace defective sleeper high speed relay (481).
Move key switch to ignition position, blower switch to high speed position, and at (481) circuit 75AH, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AH, conn. (80), and circuit 75AH, then repair.
At (481) install a test jumper from circuit 75AF to 75-GH. Disconnect conn. (48) and at circuit 75AF [coming from (481)], measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75AF, then repair.
At conn. (48) measure resistance from circuit 75-GA [going to (404)] to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GA or 11-GBB to right cab ground stud (404), then repair.
Reconnect conn. (48) and disconnect circuit 75AF from sleeper blower motor. Move key switch to ignition position, blower switch to low speed position, and at 75AF measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AF, then repair.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GA, then repair.
With ignition key in off position, reconnect circuit 75AF. Move key switch to ignition position, and with blower switch in low speed position, does blower run?
Remove medium speed relay (480), move key switch to ignition position, and move blower switch to medium speed. At circuit 75AN, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AN, conn. (80), or circuit 75AN, then repair.
Remove fuse F10-A (location may vary) and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F10-A. At relay socket (480) and circuit 75AB, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AB or 75AW, then repair.
Bench test medium speed relay (480) by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test medium speed relay (480) by applying + 12V to pin 86, ground to 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.

Disconnect conn. (48), re-install medium speed relay (480), move key switch to ignition position, and blower switch to low speed position. At (48) circuit 75AM [going to (41)], measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AM, then repair.
Disconnect resistor and thermofuse assembly (41) and reconnect conn. (48). At (41) circuit 75AM, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AM, then repair.
Reconnect resistor and thermofuse conn. (41) and remove high speed relay (481). At (481) circuit 75AD, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75AD, then repair.
Re-install high speed relay (481). Heater blower circuits check good.
